subject: Business
title: Peak-End Rule: How Experiences Are Remembered
description: A micro-lesson that makes Peak-End Rule: How Experiences Are Remembered usable.

hook.text: A 60-minute pleasant flight with turbulence at landing is remembered worse than a 60-minute rough flight with a smooth.

buildup.text: Daniel Kahneman's peak-end rule: we judge experiences by their most intense moment and how they end.

discovery.text: The total duration barely matters. A long wait with a great ending beats a short wait with a bad one.

twist.text: Most businesses optimize the beginning of experiences. The peak-end rule says the ending matters more.

climax.text: IKEA's cheap ice cream at the exit reframes a stressful shopping trip. The last moment wins.

punchline.text: Nail the ending. That's what people actually remember.

quiz.question: According to the peak-end rule, how do people judge experiences?
options: By the most intense moment and how the experience ends
By the total duration of the experience
